content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Fishing Simulator Steam Sale 2016I wanted to have my first review for something I could write fairly, not too biased, not too unknowing. Torchlight II I think fits this description.There are a few cons to Torchlight II, but they do get overthrown fairly easily with this game. So let's start with the bad.|Cons|Bugs - Yes, bugs. Not the ones you'll be killing in game or transforming your pet into either. For how long this game has been out, I was surprised to have an almost game breaking bug happen in multiplayer whenever I levelled up. My partner I was playing with would be disconnected whenever I would level. This happened for about 25 levels in game. If became a joke about having to save a million times as I was getting closer to leveling up, but it was still extremely annoying. It could've been a mod we have installed, but it has since fixed itself and said mod is still there and hasn't been updated. Pet AI - Not the greatest thing sometimes. Many times have I had a pet get stuck in a corner and not be able to move until I go back and essentially force him to move the opposite direction and then slowly walk around the corner it was getting stuck on. This doesn't happen often, but it still is a bit annoying.Fishing Time - However much I love the fishing, I hate how sometimes I can catch one in less than 3 seconds and other times I have to wait almost 20 for the circle to go grey. It adds a bit to the immersion of fish don't all bite immediately or the same, but it's still a bit of a hassle sometimes, especially to get that covetted cheevo of fishing 1000 times. Voices - I can honestly say, I don't know much about the story of the game because I can't be bothered listening to the bad voice actors of the game. Yes I can read the story, but it's more fun to just click and get back to hitting things with my sword. Truth be told though, I have a really hard time sitting there reading something when they just add massive reverb to everybody important to make them sound like a ghost or the lack of enthusiasm in most of the character's voices. Now for what we really came here for... the good stuff...|Pros|Multiplayer - Yes, it sounds crazy, a dungeon crawler Diabloesque game without multiplayer? It happened... before I bought it... hence why I have it now and not then. Great game to play multiplayer. Loot System - If you're like me and don't like playing single player with dungeon crawler games, then you'll love the loot system. No dashing in to steal everything and then break friendships for life because you Tanked and did all the damage to said boss and friend runs in and grabs your legendary class drop and wont give it to you... FML for all the times that happened. Instead, everybody has their own loot drops. Wonderful system to have and keeping friends together since 2012.Pets - Although the pet AI can stink sometimes, it's great having something to kill with. Great for tanking or ranged DPS, pets can do almost anything you can. Seriously, you can even give them spells that they can cast. It's great. There's a huge variety you can "transform" them into as well for times ranging from 5 minutes to inifite. Fishing - Again, I had my hate on for fishing earlier, but only because I have done it so much and spent hours into just sitting there in town and doing the nasty... gutting a half dead fish. 60+ bucks to sell in store or great buffs for you. Can even have your pets transform from them. Giants are a pain to get, only about 1 in 150 fishing, but still great.Mods - THANK GAWD for mods. Makes the game greater than it already is. Not as many as I would like to see, but still a great amount. It's awesome seeing a modding community that's still active with a 4 year old game (at time of posting this review... 2016).|Final Thoughts|This is the game I feel Diablo should try to take over and implement into their already decent system. It's brighter than Diablo, but I think that goes without saying. This is a great game overall and even better with friends. Do I recommend buying it for CAD $21.99? If you have a friend to play with, then yes. If you're alone, I would wait until this puppy goes on sale.|Final Score|Graphics 8.5/10Stability 6/10Sound 9/10Voices 4/10Replay Value 9.5/10Fun 9/10Overall With Voices 7.5/10True Overall 8.5/1010/10 Would fish again

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Torchlight II is one of those ARPGs that comes along and does almost everything right. I don't think I can really sit here and list all the "quality of life" improvements added for the sake of streamlined gameplay that doesn't insult the consumer's intelligence. This is a solid game that's going to be relevant for a long time, especially with Salan's Synergies Mod. Seriously, that guy is doing god's work, keeping people coming back for more. Anyway, Torchlight II is your traditional ARPG that brings a lot to the table compared to first installment. All while paralelling Diablo and Diablo II. The original heroes are present in cameos with new classes taking on the mantle in a larger setting across four chapters. Each said class breaks the mold compared to Diablo II with different ability combinations that can make for some interesting builds. Some more viable than others, but you'll rarely see an "I Win" build that dominates over all. The pet is still present, allowing you to sell your junk and even pick up supplies for you to keep you focused on the action with minimal town visits. In fact, the pet is a bit more useful with its own equipment and fish you can use to transform it to other creatures, all with different stats and special attacks or simply buffs to compliment your strategy.The settings are more vast this time, taking you across different continents, all with sidequests or hidden dungeons to explore. Socketing, gems, and skulls are still present. This time with a crafting system. You can of course merge like gems together for more powerful ones. But you can also mix/match them to generate random shards/gems with different ability sets within their theme. Plus you can do the same with items and gear, creating different rare armors/weapons, or stronger potions. Most of it is trial and error based, but part of the fun is the expiremntation. Stats and skills are thankfully spelled out in a detailed tooltip. You know what to expect from what you invest in almost down to the modifier that dictates is effectiveness. No more guessing on what stats or gear is essential, but it doesn't hold your hand either as you can play around with what primary stat you want to focus on as a modifier. Vitality is a bit useless if you're not a shield user, sadly, but socketing makes up for it. Combat is fluid, satisfying, and an excellent sense of impact. Whether you're laying waste to everything in your path with spells, sniping things from a range, swinging a giant weapon, or quickly shredding everything one by one with blinding speed, there's a sense of satisfaction to what you're doing and different gauges for each class to reward you for your relentlessness. Online gameplay is going to be hit or miss at this point. The net code is solid, but with modding and vanilla sepparated, it splits the community down the middle. At least from my point of view since I did multiplayer pre-GUTS. Now, you might have trouble finding people online, depending on your time zone. Good thing there's an offline mode too. (Obligatory jab at Diablo III)I highly reccomend Torchlight II. Not only to ARPG fans, but anyone curious about the genre as it's a great place to start. Play alone, play with friends, or make new friends while playing. More than worth the full price easily. Mod it until it crashes.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Torchlight II is one of those ARPGs that comes along and does almost everything right. I don't think I can really sit here and list all the "quality of life" improvements added for the sake of streamlined gameplay that doesn't insult the consumer's intelligence. This is a solid game that's going to be relevant for a long time, especially with Salan's Synergies Mod. Seriously, that guy is doing god's work, keeping people coming back for more. Anyway, Torchlight II is your traditional ARPG that brings a lot to the table compared to first installment. All while paralelling Diablo and Diablo II. The original heroes are present in cameos with new classes taking on the mantle in a larger setting across four chapters. Each said class breaks the mold compared to Diablo II with different ability combinations that can make for some interesting builds. Some more viable than others, but you'll rarely see an "I Win" build that dominates over all. The pet is still present, allowing you to sell your junk and even pick up supplies for you to keep you focused on the action with minimal town visits. In fact, the pet is a bit more useful with its own equipment and fish you can use to transform it to other creatures, all with different stats and special attacks or simply buffs to compliment your strategy.The settings are more vast this time, taking you across different continents, all with sidequests or hidden dungeons to explore. Socketing, gems, and skulls are still present. This time with a crafting system. You can of course merge like gems together for more powerful ones. But you can also mix/match them to generate random shards/gems with different ability sets within their theme. Plus you can do the same with items and gear, creating different rare armors/weapons, or stronger potions. Most of it is trial and error based, but part of the fun is the expiremntation. Stats and skills are thankfully spelled out in a detailed tooltip. You know what to expect from what you invest in almost down to the modifier that dictates is effectiveness. No more guessing on what stats or gear is essential, but it doesn't hold your hand either as you can play around with what primary stat you want to focus on as a modifier. Vitality is a bit useless if you're not a shield user, sadly, but socketing makes up for it. Combat is fluid, satisfying, and an excellent sense of impact. Whether you're laying waste to everything in your path with spells, sniping things from a range, swinging a giant weapon, or quickly shredding everything one by one with blinding speed, there's a sense of satisfaction to what you're doing and different gauges for each class to reward you for your relentlessness. Online gameplay is going to be hit or miss at this point. The net code is solid, but with modding and vanilla sepparated, it splits the community down the middle. At least from my point of view since I did multiplayer pre-GUTS. Now, you might have trouble finding people online, depending on your time zone. Good thing there's an offline mode too. (Obligatory jab at Diablo III)I highly reccomend Torchlight II. Not only to ARPG fans, but anyone curious about the genre as it's a great place to start. Play alone, play with friends, or make new friends while playing. More than worth the full price easily. Mod it until it crashes.

												Torchlight II is truly a great ARPG.  The base game contains hundreds of hours of game play.  Then there are challenges galore to seek!  The multiplayer is spot on with low latency game play and tons of loot.  You can have fun playing with friends or total strangers in Torchlight II.  There are randomized maps so the fun never gets stale.  And lots of difficulty mods with the option to reroll your character and start all over again!Then there is full Steam Workshop mod support.  You can alter the game into any fashion that you want.  Want to try a full set of badass armor?  You can enable it.  Want more maps?  It's there!  Want a pet that's not in the base game?  There's a mod for it.  Hell you can create it if you like!  This is truly a great game that should be in your Steam Library.  It has way more content than Diablo 3 developers could dream of in a thousand years because of the dedicated modders out there.  And it all runs seamlessly without bugs.  The code for this game is airtight!What are you waiting for?  Get Torchlight II today!

												Builds upon the first Torchlight game in every way.Played on Windows 7, iMac (2009) Yosemite, and Linux Mint 17.3. Runs great on all three OSes.PROS:+4 distinct, versatile, and fun-to-play character classes: Outlander (ranged), Berserker (melee), Ember Mage (mage), and Engineer (heavy weapons and support team).+Wider range of Pets, which will assist in battle, sell off unwanted loot, purchase needed potions, and can be taught spells.+HUGE open world, composed of three main areas and tons of side-quests and unlockable areas.+Looters' paradise. Loot can also be sold or traded when playing online.+Fun in single player, with alot of replay value beyond the initial playthrough via NG+.+Online co-op with up to 4 other players.+Enemy types are extremely varied, cool looking, and fun to battle.+Gorgeous graphics and an inviting visual aesthetic.+Windows, Mac, and Linux versions available.+Very modest hardware requirements, especially considering the amount of content in TL2.+A steal at only $20, and often on sale for even less.CONS:-Weak story. -Online co-op isn't as streamlined as other online RPGs.

												Well, this review is not for those who like this kind of RPGs. Rather, I would pen it down for those few like me who usually hate top down. Well, I love action RPGs - fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas and Skyrim are the among the best single player experiences I can remember. But when it comes to top down, I just used to have a scorn for the genre.I tried diablo 3, torchlight and torchlight 2 (a torchlight fan) at a friend's house long back. I hated it and never looked towards it for months to come. It is accidentally that I had some $4.00 in my wallet and TL2 was on sale that I purchased it. I wanted to try it again, even though I was 99% sure it won't appeal me.I was wrong. The game is GREAT. But to realize its greatness, there are three things you must keep in mind:- Don't think that you are playing an action game. There is very little skill of swiftness on mouse and keyboard required in this game. So, definitely not an action game.- Play it for at least 15 hours, level up to level 25 and then judge.... things keep on adding, new skills start appearing, interesting scrolls begin dropping out of chests and skilled monsters... it is then that you understand how amazing this game is.- If you are dying more, it is not that you are not able to deliver enough clicks-per-second, it just means that each of the clicks has an ignorantly cascaded set of skills behind it. So, activate the right skills and wear the right armor. I started learning new things about the mechanics when I was 3 hours into the game and am learning totally new things till now (e.g. For torchlight 2 players - sets of armor... the purple thing written in some armor's description... something I learnt at mty 29th hour).I played the game for 15 hours on normal, realized that I was very ignorant about the game's mechanics, deleted my character, started a veteran character and adorned it with better perks this time... continuing with it.... glad that I started the game again..HAPPY GAMING!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												A great RPG that I could recommend to anyone.Torchlight II is an absolutely gigantic game with tons of possibilities. There are 4 different classes which all have their strenghts and weaknesses. Each class has 3 different skill trees which contain both passive and active skills. Most skills require you to be a pretty high level though, so getting your desired skills and have them at a high rank will definitely take you some time.The levels in Torchlight are huge! They are filled with lots of enemies, NPCs and objects that will have you fighting and exploring for a while. After you've completed the game, you have the chance to play a few bonus maps with various buffs and de-buffs or you can decide to play the game over again with the same character, but with the enemies adjusted to your current character level.There's also a big variety of weapons in the game. Melee weapons like staves, spears, axes, swords and ranged weapons like crossbows, guns and wands. Some classes have skills in their skill tree that allows you to increase your proficiency with a certain weapon type. Torchlight II has an added workshop which allows you to make use of the many mods that are made for this game. Mods can add different characters, game mechanics or even more weapons like throwing axes, throwing knives and claws.All of that said, I can definitely recommend Torchlight II to anyone that is into Hack and Slash RPGs. Prepare for hours of fun and tons of achievements to unlock!

												It is inevitable to compare this game to Blizzard's hack 'n slash RPG. I would say this would be the poor-man's version of Diablo III, but the truth of the matter is Torchlight II holds it's ground and could even be considered a better game overall, depending on what you're looking for.Torchlight II brings better loot, better progressions system, mob variety and arguably a better 'end-game'. The only two thing it lacks, compared to Diablo III, is the graphical fidelity (although since the game is done in a cartoonish art-style, it is not immediately noticable) and story.While Torchlight II manages to win points in the atmosphere department, the story of the Diablo universe offers a much more expanded lore and world to explore. Voice acting, cinematics and sound design are far better than what Torchlight II has. Which is to be expected from a series that started it's roots in indie gaming. Experience sharing in multiplayer could use some tweaking, but loot is instanced for every player and trading is fully functional for all items you find. A big plus for the game is also mod support, something which Diablo III lacks. The Steam Workshop is sure to increase the life-span of the game, and enchance the experience according to your taste buds.Despite some of it's shortcomings, it is still one of the better hack 'n slash RPGs out there. Definitely worth your time!

												Torchlight II is a really good game, but not a great game. It has an endearing art-style that's easy on the eyes, and the gameplay is addictive enough to keep you playing 'till the end (I played about 50 hours by the time I beat it). However, there is nothing about this game that is exceptional or raises the bar. The story isn't deep or engaging, and the world lacks depth. Had the developers expanded the towns and added sub characters to strengthen the plot, then this game could have been a bench mark. The loot drops are well-balanced and look decent, the world is visually appealing, even interesting in some places, and the monsters are well-designed. But beyond the relentless grind, there's nothing much motivating you to keep collecting and throwing away loot 'till the next boss fight, except more loot and boss fights, that is. If you're just looking for a game to help you pass the time without being bored, then it does its job well, but don't expect an engaging story to justify the 50+ hours you may waste playing it. In the end, I feel like I got my money's worth, but only based on what I already kind of expected.

												A great RPG that I could recommend to anyone.Torchlight II is an absolutely gigantic game with tons of possibilities. There are 4 different classes which all have their strenghts and weaknesses. Each class has 3 different skill trees which contain both passive and active skills. Most skills require you to be a pretty high level though, so getting your desired skills and have them at a high rank will definitely take you some time.The levels in Torchlight are huge! They are filled with lots of enemies, NPCs and objects that will have you fighting and exploring for a while. After you've completed the game, you have the chance to play a few bonus maps with various buffs and de-buffs or you can decide to play the game over again with the same character, but with the enemies adjusted to your current character level.There's also a big variety of weapons in the game. Melee weapons like staves, spears, axes, swords and ranged weapons like crossbows, guns and wands. Some classes have skills in their skill tree that allows you to increase your proficiency with a certain weapon type. Torchlight II has an added workshop which allows you to make use of the many mods that are made for this game. Mods can add different characters, game mechanics or even more weapons like throwing axes, throwing knives and claws.All of that said, I can definitely recommend Torchlight II to anyone that is into Hack and Slash RPGs. Prepare for hours of fun and tons of achievements to unlock!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Many dungeon crawlers pride themselves on lootporn. Runic Games realises it's nice to also package in an actual game with your Excel sheet, and manages to build an inviting world with a responsive and satisfying combat system.The game's story is one of tragic desperation, told across 4 acts, and while I won't spoil anything I suggest you not play this for its storyline, as it doesn't go far nor deep. Don't mistake this for a lack of charm though, as each of the game's environments are colourful and varied. From bright shining deserts to gloomy forests and snowy ... cold places. My eyes were never bored.The four classes available in the game all have their distinctive styles, but also allow for a large amount of customisation on the player's part. Many different active abilities are available to choose from, which translates to many different ways to play. Within the admittedly limited amount of classes I can almost guarantee anyone will find a build they're comfortable with. A minor point against this is that respeccing is not available in the base game. Modding rectifies this.Which brings me to my next point: The players. This game has an abundance of that whole consumer-friendliness our industry seems to relish in not caring about. You want mod support? It's in there, ranging from the smallest of tweaks to total conversions. Always online DRM? Don't be so daft, play offline if you like and have a lovely experience. What about LAN? Yeah, LAN support is in, go nuts. Also note the apparent lack of any microtransactions or locked-behind-paywalls DLC. The point I'm trying to make is that if you take the direction of the industry into account when you're considering a purchase, this is definitely not the worst option available.Lastly, I should point you to its price. This game doesn't exactly break the bank compared to most other releases of this scope. HowLongToBeat.com lists the average main story completion takes around 20 hours, that's not counting the side quests in the field, extra dungeons, mapworks (endgame dungeons) or New Game Plus mode.So what have we got? A 20ish hour flat story with a pleasing coat of paint, well flowing and varied options for combat, single- online- and LAN play and excellent mod support packed into what is a relatively inexpensive game. If your interest has been piqued I highly recommend you play this game, but if you’re on the fence I suggest having a go with the free demo first.

												Yes, yes... This is a good game... I've yet to complete the game but I'll add more comments when I do. There are so many similarities to Diablo but so many other interesting things as well. I've listed them down in the PROS and CONS.TL2 is slightly below Diablo in terms of content quantity... 4 levels are really, really fast to finish.... But for the price, it was worth it.... I am also very annoyed with the creation of another Runic account to link to my Steam account. I would like to be able to transfer my game to another Steam account not the one I bought it with. Another pet peeve (which can't be helped) is the feeling of repetition deeper into TL2. You can see copies of Ratlings, skeletons and Brutes appearing over and over again. They just come back with a different name and different skin.$4.00 SGDPROS1. Great map designQuests and story rolled into one. Not all the quests are in the town, some are hidden away in the map, so it makes you want to explore. However, the downside is that you might miss some of these quests as you don't know where they are. E.g. Zephari Envoy2. SecretsThere are lots of interesting secret areas. One memorable one was "It puts the lotion in the bucket" (obvious reference to Silence of the Lambs). I shouldn't spoil how to do it but let's just say it will be interesting to find the lotion.3. Skill treesI like the way you can upgrade your skills and that there are so many skills to work with, per character. Each skill is tiered into T1, T2, T3 with a special upgrade at each tier. There are a lot of way to play your character.4. Semi-Live NPCsThe NPCs give you information on current events which are related to your quests and they don't function purely as lamp posts. I think they could have made it better by making the NPCs come alive even more though.5. Train TravelAlthough a cut-scene, it was cool. I was hoping to interact with the train though. I think that it would be better if we could go onto the train and do stuff on it.6. InteractionQuite a few items but not everything. You can break urns, rocks, explosives and barrels but those are a given. Lighting the braziers to provide light was most innovative. I think having levers or switchs that moved big bridges would be quite cool.7. Knocking creatures offThere are some ways to knock off tiny land creatures, off the terrain and into a pit. Very cool, much better than an invisible ring. Of course, you can be knocked off as well.8. Pack mule / PetI love my pet and the ability to sell items without going back to town. 9. Spider MinesI can't believe there are spider mines that seek out enemies.10. Alternate weaponsPress W. Switch from range to melee. Great move. Change playstyle instantly. *Star star*11. NPC huntingYou can get more NPCs to help out in the town if you go out of your way to do side quests. Again, a potential pitfall as you might miss them totally, but it's okay. The similarity to Suikoden's hero collection is great.CONS1. BugsCan't pick up items that fall onto ledgesCan't shoot creatures who are no more than a few feet above or below you.2. Murder HoboAlmost everything is still mass murder. Kill, kill, kill, kill and more killing for any quest. I'm a mass murderer in this game. I've yet to come across a quest without premeditated murder.3. Stupid thingsYou are face-to-face with an enemy. However, you can't reach him because of a crack that runs through the floor, dividing you and the enemy. Most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I think a jump would be great.4. Runic Account creationMost annoying. I have to create another account just to play online. <------ This here pisses me off.5. Spell keys1,2,3,4 are easy to reach. 5,6,7,8,9,0 extremely hard. Would have been better with 1234QWER.6. RepetitionRatlings, goo, skeletons repeated. Just with a different colour palette and skin.7. FameWhat does this do?8. ContentOnly 4 levels. I breezed through them. It didn't feel like there was enough interesting stuff. Just lots of similar level bashing.NEUTRAL1. Trash dropsI am not so certain about trash drops that just keep on generating a lot of junk for me to sell. Perhaps, something else can be done about trash drops?SUGGESTIONSI saw ladders in the game. Could Runic code an interaction with ladders?

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Torchlight II reminds me of a couple of other typical "looter" games such as "Diablo" or the latest F2P game "Path of Exile". However, a few features ultimately standout from these other games which is why I highly recommend this game over the others. First, you do not have to be a diehard gamer in order to play this game. There are 4 difficulty tiers, and even the second tier (normal) feels relatively easy to an experienced player, even if you have never played another looter-type game. Second, since it is mainly a point-and-click-RPG game, one may believe they would get tired of the game after but a few moments. This is hardly the case as all the little features and nuances work beautifully together to bring you an experience that is immediately rewarding and highly addictive unlike other alternatives. Lastly, while it is a relatively fast-paced game, it seems to be more manageable in the gameplay department across the board for any player in comparison to what I have seen from Path of Exile. This just further demonstrates that just because it is free, does not mean that is better for you in the long run. Oh, and the best part is...I've only been talking about the single player experience. This game also possesses a co-op feature so you can play through the story with several friends, or even random strangers. Player trading is also included, so expect hours to pass by if you play this game with people you enjoy being around and love killing creatures with them. Now Torchlight II does have a few odd in-game features to it I've noticed. For one, the blood animations do not seem even remotely realistic (even by fantasy standards). You could kill an enemy and they would first explode followed by the entire wall being entirely covered in blood...which the wall could be 10 times your size and your enemy's size, so this makes absolutely no sense. Also, the enemies sometimes get stuck in the most random places, which allows you to easily snipe them and pick away at their health continuously if you like utilizing a ranged character and those style tactics. I've already done this with a few mini-bosses and laughed all the while. Lastly, I honestly wish I did not have to click for every attack. I wish there was some auto-attack feature after you have targeted an enemy, but this is just me being nit-picky at this point. If you notice, these are just minor issues as well. I have seen no major problems or adversities to mention from this game so far as you can plainly see as well.Ultimately, Torchlight II provides a unique, personalized, open world experience which gives games such as the Diablo series a run for its money, especially when it is on sale in the steam store. I highly recommend picking this game up when it is on sale, as you will not be disappointed with the many hours you will invest into this game alone or with friends. Now, excuse me as I go bandage up my index finger for the next extensive click-fest that I am about to perform in this game.

Product received for free
What Is Torchlight II?Torchlight II is one of those wildly popular Steam games which hardly requires any introduction for fans of isometric-style action RPG's. Developed by Runic Games in 2012 as a more polished and refined version of its previous incarnation (Torchlight), it is widely hailed and beloved by scores of fanatical gamers (well over 3 million+) for its many favorable similarities to the equally popular Diablo series.The true hallmark of this title however, is that the sprawling world it offers to you on a very reasonably priced silver platter is a gorgeously inviting one awaiting to be explored to its fullest....tempting you with countless secrets to uncover & treasures to collect. In fact there is more loot to be found hidden within its myriad of locations than you could possibly wrap your mind around. It's easily one of those gems with which you can sink hundreds of hours into, since it offers level randomization for enhanced replayability inside of its open world system...one which includes weather as well as day/night cycles incidentally.GameplayFeaturing a very tight local + online co-op mode (in addition to solo offline play), you'll soon notice that you will be introduced to a diverse bounty of seemingly never-ending quests & side-quests given to you by those who require your assistance in one way or another. And fortunately, you'll have a ferocious pet by your side to help out in battle as needed, one who even possesses its own inventory!  In addition to the exploration and loot collecting, your primary objective will be to battle against a wide assortment of variously menacing monsters as you gradually level up your character with more skills, gold, and gear during this compelling campaign. Action is very fluid, brisk, and energetic...with a satisfying number of both weapon upgrades and weapon types (including melee & guns) to keep you more than entertained.Both your mana (ie. energy) and health bars will be depleted during combat, and must be replenished as necessary with collected vials which can be used up at any time.Character customization is present, although somewhat limited and basic in scope I felt. It's probably the most glaring aspect of the game which could have been improved further still. Nonetheless, it is still present at least, and you'll have your choice of either male/female characters spread across 4 distinct classes: Embermage, Outlander, Berserker, Engineer.Level design was quite impressive & varied in an overall sense, with some specific areas like the dungeons being especially atmospheric. It was quite a joy for me to explore every single nook & cranny of each individual section traversed as I hunted around for items to collect between waves of enemies....who themselves were sufficiently unique enough throughout the campaign so as to not feel repetitious in any way.There is just so very much to do in the game, and even after investing a few quality hours into it, there was an undeniable feeling that I've still only barely scratched the surface as to what awaits me further into its story.GraphicsWhat I especially appreciated about the presentation, is that this world is surprisingly vibrant in color as opposed to being dreary & muted looking in appearance as some other such similar games are. Which is then reinforced furthermore by the distinctly cartoon-style graphics found here. This in turn is all neatly tied together by a very well-done lighting system which somehow breathes a sense of intriguing realism into this magical place. All in all, it is quite pleasant on the eyes and sports a unique charm to it. And best of all, there are an ample number of graphics options available for fine-tuning your display preferences.AudioVoice acting was definitely above par, and sounded quite slick for the many varied characters present. (Although at times I felt that your character's obsession with his depleted mana levels was a bit overly-repetitive!). Whereas music itself was mellow & symphonic in nature...wonderfully balancing out the mood of each particular scene in an appropriate manner. And finally, sound effects were more than adequate in accomplishing their task of enhancing immersion...especially so with delightful effects such as thunder reverberating through the rainy night, for example. Steamified?It fully is, and includes both trading cards and a whopping 119 achievements to be unlocked.DLCNone available.ModsThe vast collection of available mods via the Steam Workshop is where this game truly shines like no other. There are literally hundreds of them to choose from in every possible category imaginable, and quite honestly you could find pretty much anything your little heart desires here.Verdict - 9/10Torchlight II has to be one of the best values out there in ARPG's...because while it only costs a fraction of what its pricier triple-A competitors do, it nonetheless very much competes as one, and more importantly, feels like one with its overhauled & redesigned user-interface which was a breeze to use. Accessibility is fantastic here as well, showcasing a streamlined and mostly straight-forward character leveling system which I greatly appreciated. Because being hopelessly confused inside of skill trees is not my personal idea of a fun time, and here, they most certainly get it right in steering the focus onto actual gameplay instead. And along with its multiple difficulty settings, just about anyone can enjoy what it has to offer...from the very casual side of the spectrum for those who simply wish to explore its scenery, all the way up to the no-nonsense hardcore setting for those veterans out there who wish to master its more subtle nuances. All in all, Torchlight II has underwent quite a lot of refinement to date, and runs at fantastic framerates even on less than cutting-edge hardware. But most of all, this is an exciting world to step inside of and one which you can very much have a great time with since there is always something interesting to do along with an accompanying sense of accomplishment felt as each goal is successfully completed...and that is why...I'll gladly rate this one a 9/10Pros:- Many hours of fun with lots to do and much to explore- Impressively designed & vast isometric world with vibrantly colorful aesthetics- Wonderfully implemented dynamic zoom camera- Nice selection of weapons + gear- Can play as both male or female- Great value for the purchase price- Rebindable keys- Impressive amount of adjustable graphics options- Local/online co-op + offline single-player - Steam achievements + trading cards- Countless mods available via the Steam WorkshopCons:- Character customization system could be more robust- Some of the character speech is repeated a bit too often For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												*This review will be downvoted to hell by fans*Summary:Torchlight II clings to its Diablo series heritage like no other. It tries to be, at the same time, both fresh and familiar to fans of the genre. In the end, It’s just a cartoony Diablo II clone with elaborated gameplay mechanics. Both gives a mixture that seems appetizing but in reality is just stale and plain boring.6/10The Good :- Many, many weapons and items- Pets- Overally polished- Good musicThe Bad :- Very repetitive gameplay, even for hack'n'slash- Bland atmosphere and plot- Feels like cartoony clone of Diablo II- Dated graphicsI did not finish the game. My review follows these situations rarely. Even more rarely, I’m struggling to like something. This time, it’s Torchlight II.As serious as I can be, this fight ensued the moment I started the game and ceased when it ended up in a virtual dump. Don’t get me wrong, I adore hack’n’slash RPG’s.I absolutely loved Diablo I and more so, Diablo II. First part created the genre with gloomy atmosphere and revolutionary gameplay. The sequel had the magic to keep you clicking so many times, one would believe you’re testing mouse manufacturer’s claims of billion click durability. Torchlight II has neither. And here’s why.Right of the bat, Torchlight II shows resemblance to Diablo II. Made by the same author, the music is unmistakable. At first, I was glad because I really enjoy these notes but at the same time it prevents Torchlight to be unique. Several sounds, like opening a teleport, are basically cloned from Diablo II. Even the sequence of worlds and it’s hubs in TL are the same as Diablo II – wilderness, desert, dense forest, hell. And just like in Diablo II, our nemesis is a mysterious traveler that we’re always one step behind from. All of this takes away from Torchlight II. It’s just too familiar to call it a world of its own. It’s a copy with cartoony overlay which makes it neither dark and gloomy, nor light-hearted.As years passed, hack’n’slash games had to mutate it’s formula to remain fresh and attractive to gamers. Happily, Torchlight II has some tweaks and non-standard ideas, one of which is company of your pet. Essentialy, it’s your coop friend. There are several pets to choose from, all of which can pick and store items for you, wear accessories, fight, cast spells and last but totally not list, do a little shoppin while you bash evil’s head. You can also fish for, well, fishes that for reasons unknown, can transform your pet into a killing beast.As It goes for Diablo clones, you have a lot to choose from to do that. Beside leveling, getting a good equipment is the core element of action RPG’s. Torchlight II gives you –collecting sets, enchanting, socketing and putting in gems. Unfortunately, beside collecting and buying spells that can be used by any class, I can’t find anything that discerns Torchlight from other ARPG’s. Speaking of classes, I didn’t play every class. I focused mainly on Engineer. What I found out, is that I played through majority of the game using only 4 out of dozens. I’ve tried more variety but I’ve always ended up coming back to previous skills as they work best. So it all came down to getting the right equipment. Though you’ll encounter or buy many, many stuff it’s not that easy to find an upgrade. I’ve completed 3/4 of the game using just 3 ranged weapons with a single tactic. Single tactic, because even though monsters seem to vary much, the’re all killed the same. On hard difficulty I didn’t though that Tourchlight II is challenging, not even for a wihle)That said, it was hard to not get bored. Accompanied by generic maps, plot that isn’t worth mentioning (which I won’t) and repetitiveness with no challenge, I was struck with remorse while playing Torchlight II. Remorse that told me, that time with Torchlight II could be spent way better or at least on a superior game. Torchlight II is an OK ARPG, that excels in mediocrity. If ARPG’s are your thing, you could bite the bullet, especially that it’s dirt cheap now, but don’t say that I didn’t warn you.

												After sitting down for 13 hours straight to complete this game -including all the sidequests-, I've found gameplay to be pretty fun with all the unique skills available. HOWEVER that being said it's evident that the story is short and the endgame content is just simply a grind much like how Diablo 2 functions. The enemies' HP bars just turn into skill-soaking sponges that are only there to delay you for 5-10 seconds just for that 0.1mm xp bar gain. I will comment on the very nice smooth visual aspects of the game, the artwork for the game and the texture quality will not leave your eyes sore after bingle playing it.Runic games did fix the one balance issue I saw from TL1 which was the pet meta where you would just summon everything to kill stuff for you while you just walked around. Gameplay is still lacking a bit because in the endgame you just need to healtank with potions that drop from ♥♥♥♥in everything ALONG WITH the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t aegis shield that you could proc which was basically 4x your normal health. Stuff like this leads away from interesting and interactive gameplay because you can just stand in the middle of everything pressing 1-9 and watching the visuals go off until everything around you is dead without much thought, hell near the end I just opened up youtube and watched Dota videos while I grinded maps because it's simply so braindead at times. To be honest the story is pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ but thats up for you to decide. Now I know most of you will say that mods make this game better but I can't acknowledge that due to the fact that I never touched mods and even with mods the endgame is still a dead grind.The game is worth the $20 to buy it but it goes on sale so much it's probably worth $10 at most. Runic Games has no plans to release a TL3 which saddens me. I love TL2 but I just don't love it enough to see myself logging on every day to grind for nothing.Game is fun for a period of time. Really though, it just turns into a grind with pretty visuals.  If you're into grindy dungeoncrawlers I suggest you milk all the playability out of this game and move on to Diablo 2.

												This is perhaps one of the best point-and-click fantasy RPG games I have had the pleasure of playing. Not only are there different difficulties and online, a massive selection of pets, multiplayer servers that host up to six players at a time, but the story line and characters are highly interesting.There are four classes to choose from, a mage, an engineer, a gun-slinger, and the classic bezerker. Each has their own special trait that makes each unique and desirable to different types of players. Choosing a class doesn't limit you to their stereotypical equipment, though! Being a dual axe-weilding Embermage and being questioned about  why  I use axes instead of a staff or wand is just a portion of the fun!I am what I presume to be about one-third of the way through the game judging by level and achievement progress, though I intend to continue playing after I complete the game with my current character. Perhaps the biggest problem I'm facing is my pet hawk being so much more powerful than me. then again, I suppose I am the one that taught it such powerful spells and provided stat-boosting equipment in the form of a collar and tags.One of my most recent side quests had me help a man recover masks in an attempt to bring peace to two warring races, and though I won't spoil all the details, it was a perfect, "Plot twist!!!" moment that had me grin and facepalm at my want to help (And need for xp!)  He turned out to be evil and needed the masks to gain power. Whoopsies! Was fun defeating him though~ Overall, I would suggest this game to anyone that enjoys RPG-style games that finds others hard to run due to system requirements. The minor issues I experience are not enough to subtract from the experience and pleasure of this game. A 9.5/10

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Crowborn's Review of Torchlight II-Ever since I was a boy, and got my hands on Diablo 1, I have been a fan of the hack-n-slash game-genre. Something about the game strung a cord inside of me, and I played it almost non-stop for years. Same with the sequel - it kept me busy through highschool and sane in the awkward years following when I was rampaging through life, trying to figure out what the 'eck I wanted to do. And so arrived the highly anticipated 3rd installment of the Diablo genre - to lackluster reviews. I picked it up immediately of course, but I were never able to enjoy it. It just seemed off to me, seemed strange, like an orange growing on an apple-tree, trying to fit in with the smooth green skinned fellas around it. But for me it failed at the deceit, and I put down the game after playing it for only a few months. Dissapointed and bereft of one of my favourite genres, I started looking around for substitutes. That's when I heard about Torchlight II.I had noticed the series before, but for some reason never gotten around to trying it out. It was supposed to be a fairly good diablo-clone, and while I liked the genre, it wasn't until one of my dear steam-friends gifted me the game, that I actually managed to sit down and play it. I felt obliged to, so to say. And my were I pleasantly surprised!Torchlight II is a really well made game. From the steam-punkish world, cross the interesting skill-sets, to the actio-packed maps - this game just breathes fun game design. Granted, the game is 'very' much a Diablo-clone, and anyone who ever played those games will immediately find everything intimately familiar. But that's not a bad thing. In fact, I find it darned good. I didn't have to read a bible of game-guides before daring to venture out in the the world of Torchlight, and hack and slash my way through the first pack of monsters I came across. It granted me immediate satisfaction and loads of fun.It feels to me like the devs of this game did right, what the guys at Blizz did wrong. Torchlight II follows to a point the tried and true old recipe of hack-n-slash. They don't try to reinvent or alter the genre, but instead stick to what works and 'has' worked for the last two decades. You got your attribute-points, your skill-points, random loot, runes and enchantments to upgrade your gear, rewarding exploration, and a story-line that doesn't distract you from your dungeon-delving fun.The game hearkens back to the good old days, and gives the players exactly what they expected - and a little more. It deserves a top grade, but due to an at times non-transparent stat-system and unbalanced characters, I have to subtract a few points. I give it:8.5/10

												I've played a lot of ARPGs which all started with Diablo 2, and I've always craved a similar experience. Recently, or should I say last year, Diablo 3 came out, and to every single Diablo fan, it was an abysmal failure. I won't go into the details but I wasted 200hrs of my life playing that game and hoping it would get better. I eventually moved on and a few months ago picked up Path of Exile, which is another prominent ARPG that actually came out fairly recently. It was great until I started getting to higher difficulties, and whenever I died I lost a TON of experience. All my hard work farming and grinding would go to waste. Additionally, the whole gem skill system was too tedious and required lot of micromanagement to get the skills to work like I wanted them too. Alas, I got back into Torchlight 2 and hoped for a fresh start. This game, initially, made me hesistant because of its cartoony artstyle since I was used to the Dark Fantasy type worlds of POE and D3. But, eventually I started to play  and got over that fact. The gameplay was enjoyable. For example, I enjoyed the fact we could distribute attributes early on and start to specialize in a type of skill set. But what got me hooked on this game was the Loot System and how it was so rewarding to defeat challenging dungeon bosses as well as get great Uniques and Legendaries. Plus, the environment and the side missions, like phase portals, were so unique and everchanging compared to other ARPGs. Also, the end game option like Mapworks and New Game plus adds infinite replayability. This game in essence is what ARPGs should be about. I'm glad I bought this game.

Posted: December 10, 2012
												Torchlight II would be amazing if there was more of an end-game to speak of. The multiplayer is a huge step in the right direction, but Runic's not there just yet. Gimpy PVP is a non-factor and a low item diversity means every character of a given class is shooting for the exact same gear at level 100. Game modifications and saving character files locally is a double-edged sword; while it is nice to have community contributions, it also makes cheating a breeze. Difficulty scaling is rather uneven through New Game Plus 2 and beyond, and characters that have advanced that far are unable to join games or play with those that are not on the same stage of NG+ progression. While I wish there was a broader meta, this is still the best loot-'em-up I've played since Diablo II.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												If you liked Diablo 2, you'll love this game. While the story and composition are almost exactly identical to D2, there are a few changes that I absolutely loved. I found the skills very approachable, you can make your build as simple or as complex as you want, and most builds are effective. You can no longer upgrade gems the same way, so you don't need to feel compelled to collect and keep all the gems. They added a limited ability to respec your character, so you have a few levels to play around with skill choices, which I found useful. However, the most notable change (for me) is the independent treasure drops. There is no longer a mad scramble for the best loot if you play multiplayer. You can take all the loot you see, which made multiplayer infinitely more enjoyable for me.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												I've played a lot of ARPGs which all started with Diablo 2, and I've always craved a similar experience. Recently, or should I say last year, Diablo 3 came out, and to every single Diablo fan, it was an abysmal failure. I won't go into the details but I wasted 200hrs of my life playing that game and hoping it would get better. I eventually moved on and a few months ago picked up Path of Exile, which is another prominent ARPG that actually came out fairly recently. It was great until I started getting to higher difficulties, and whenever I died I lost a TON of experience. All my hard work farming and grinding would go to waste. Additionally, the whole gem skill system was too tedious and required lot of micromanagement to get the skills to work like I wanted them too. Alas, I got back into Torchlight 2 and hoped for a fresh start. This game, initially, made me hesistant because of its cartoony artstyle since I was used to the Dark Fantasy type worlds of POE and D3. But, eventually I started to play  and got over that fact. The gameplay was enjoyable. For example, I enjoyed the fact we could distribute attributes early on and start to specialize in a type of skill set. But what got me hooked on this game was the Loot System and how it was so rewarding to defeat challenging dungeon bosses as well as get great Uniques and Legendaries. Plus, the environment and the side missions, like phase portals, were so unique and everchanging compared to other ARPGs. Also, the end game option like Mapworks and New Game plus adds infinite replayability. This game in essence is what ARPGs should be about. I'm glad I bought this game.

												I enjoyed Torchlight 2.  Its play style is very similar to Blizzard's Diablo 3.  Some reasons I like Torchlight 2 more than Diablo 3:1) no real money auction house circus hyping microtransaction-to-win (I guess even Blizzard conceded how bad that was by finally removing it from D3)2) Your pet has inventory and can be sent to town to sell trash drops and/or buy potions, scrolls, etc.. On sale, which is not uncommon, it made Diablo 3 pricing look flat out offensive.If Diablo 3 has an obvious advantage, it's probably their art/story talent and budget, which is what we've come to expect from Blizzard, and would be tough for even the most capable publishers to compete with.I recommend Torchlight 2 to anybody interested in playing this style of action RPG.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Really fun game! This is my first foray into the action-rpg/dungeon genre, and I love it. +The art style is gorgeous, and they've done a great job of making so many armours and weapons not look fugly. -When it gets really hectic it can be difficult to see what's going on through all the bright colours and effects.+The New Game system is cool; you won't be near max level after you finish the story, so you can start NG+and do the areas over again, but with your character at a higher level and all the loot and mosters have been scaled appropriately+Mapworks feature adds some good replayability. Adds many different dungeons with different stats (eg, monsters drop double gold, monsters immune to crits, double exp, double gold, etc)+Having the pet is handy! It has its own inventory, and you can send it to town to sell or pick up certain items. You can also get gear to boost their health and damage, which is nice for ranged builds!+Amazing amount of build versatility. Not limited by your class to any weapon or play style, so there's a tonne of fun to be had in making a ridiculous or strange build and rolling with it.~ Not all builds are viable though, and sometimes you have to remake a character a couple hours in because you've built poorly. (Or, yay respec mods!)-even with many play styles available, the overall gameplay can get repetitve after awhile.+Multiplayer is a lot of fun. Definitely a game I prefer as a multiplayer game to single player. The difficulty scales according to how many party members are around and it's a lof of fun going crazy with your friends,+The ability to switch your character very easily between single player, multiplayer (LAN) and multiplayer (online) is great, other games do do this but I've found Torchlight's simplicity is really helpful.-It can be difficult connecting to online games some times, and lag does happen where your friend freezes on your screen but you can move, but vice versa on theirs. Makes for confusing runs sometimes.This game is a tonne of fun. I picked it up on a suggestion from a friend when it was $5, and it's probably the most I've ever gotten out of five dollars. I'd not hesitate even for the full $20!

												Sometimes a game of this type comes along and does so many things right, that it's hard to say anything bad about it. If you like Diablo style fun this game will blow your mind! The Dungeons are fun, the classes are great and the world is fluid and lovingly crafted. Immersion never feels forced in Torchlight 2! You'll find yourself playing this game to realise your characters maximum potential for your chosen style of play/build, and then putting it to the test. Personally I get a giggle every time I send my pet to to town to sell the crap I've laden  it's bag with, such a great feature that, which means you can get on with your killing (if you dare going alone!).  And when you're done, you can get content from the Steam Workshop to extend your game play, and even add 3+ more classes, more dungeons, and even raids! Hell, if you're into content creation and a little know-how, you can get the GUTS tool and make your own!Once you're set up to play on-line you can play your game either on LAN or Internet, and your friends can join you in your adventure, and trade goodies to each other! There is a small hassle setting up an on-line account and linking it to your steam account on the game website, and then add friends so you can play on-line with them. It's nothing hard, but I've heard the picky few complain xD. If you're playing in Mod Mode (Steam workshop addons), you have to make sure your friends are running the same ones, in order to play together, otherwise it's pretty straightforward :DPersonal Rating: Great Game, worthy of any libraryScore Rating: 92% - Nearly a Classic!

Posted: June 11, 2014
												Torchlight II is an incredible action RPG in the top-down, point-and-click style of Diablo. Having played both Diablo III and this game, I must say that I found Torchlight II preferable. Many call it "Diablo with guns" but Torchlight II is much more than that. The handy pet system gives you both a battle companion and a courier, carrying your unwanted loot back to town and selling it automatically. The extend of character customization permitted is also much greater than in Diablo. The combat feels much less detached and more engaging, which is a welcome tweak. The greatest advantage of Torchlight II is that you don't have to be constantly connected to the internet to play. You can play solo offline and even play co-op over LAN. In that regard, Torchlight II is much more respectful of you as a customer.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												WARNING- I have only played up to part way through act 2 of this game, but I have experience with all classes. I have not played the multiplayer.If you like ARPGs, you have probably already bought this game, so do not need to to recommend it to you. I don't. For what it's worth, Torchlight II is much better than it's predecessor, consisting of better, meatier combat as well as multiplayer and better difficulty. As an ARPG, it is near perfection, but as a game I find it somewhat lacking. Weapons like the shotgun and cannon could be meatier, and fighting with a melee character seems to lack impact. The game attempts to seem open world, but considering that I would have to clear out every area simply to keep up with levels, it misses the point entirely. In my opinion, the point of open world is that things are OPTIONAL- you could explore the nearby cave, or you could not. Removing that basically makes the concept useless. Mobility is done well, with dodging a powerful blow feeling very satisfying and fun, however there are some attacks that simply curve around to hit me again, removing the satisfaction. Bosses are similarly very satisfying, but also very dangerous and difficult to avoid- with a great feeling when you beat them.The skill system is not innovative, but generally well done- nothing more to say here. The dark music provides an interesting contrast to the cartoony art style, but I feel that the story simply isnt dark enough to fully support that contrast. However, most of the problems mentioned before are nitpicking, and the main game is stellar for its genre.If you like ARPGs, you will love this game, but it wont turn you onto the genre if you hate them.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												If you are as devoted of a fan to the Runic team as I am, then this sequel is for you. Great feel and vibe and plays just as great if not better than Torchlight. Also if you are not familiar with Torchlight but loved playing Diablo I and II then both Torchlight games are for you. The only thing thats really changed in this game is the fact that the TP scroll works as a designated waypoint and it makes it to were you do not have to use regular waypoints (Just like in Torchlight and Diablo I & II) to get around quickly, which is convienent because it doesnt go away when you go back through it. However you cannot  place them in Boss chambers/instances. Gold however is not as easily accumulated because its in very small proportions throughout the world but collecting loot and the gold will give you an ample stockpile. With that said, you cannot stash gold like you could in previous Runic developments and Torchlight I, but maybe its a mod that I havent looked into yet for Torclight II. In closing, great game, and multiplayer is fun but its more of game you must have a friend to play with, mainly because the online community is small. If you have $20 extra pick it up, you wont regret it.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Torchlight II: An amazing ARPG that has made significant improvements over the first, and comes along with strong exploration elements. Also, it has multiplayer, which is great.If you ever were a fan of the FATE series or the first Torchlight, this is a must. It's overall gameplay is much better than the first Torchlight, but it still keeps the theme.Combat has been drastically improved. The classes are generally more fun, but a little more unbalanced; the ranged class does very little compared to the berserker, unless you're with a group.Exploration is the strongest point of this game. The visuals are breathtaking for an overhead ARPG. The environments are huge, and the dungeons are menacing.The only noticable downside I see in this game is that the first few hours seemed rather dull to me. When I got later into the game, though, it became very interesting. Also, the environments are static, meaning they aren't procedurally generated. This isn't really a bad thing, it allows for much more detail in the levels, and detail I saw. It just means there isn't as much replay value. So once you beat the game, you might hesitate starting over again.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												It lost some of the great functions of the first one, like the gems adding up to being better on the trasmuter, instead now they just turn into blood ember, chaos ember, iron ember or void ember, of the respective level. Although I can get why they did this, so you don't get stuck on farm hunting these gems into despair, they made it easy for you to farm them, so you now can get them progressing through the game.The visuals tend to have a grand variety through the game, as you can have an icy tundra first, then have an hot desert the next. Animations are fluid and creative, but it's sad that for the most part the only thing you see is the slicing of flesh and a splatter of blood covering your screen when it's full of monsters. But they did improve a lot on the different type of monsters on the account of the first, let alone the animations that accompany their entrances into the map, which is a nice feature to not just have them all roaming the map.The gameplay is still as fast as the first, where the only time you have to breath is the time you choose, since you don't have to stop by the town everytime you need to sell your items. The monsters, champions and bosses all present their unique signature attacks, that make you adjust your tactic on how to aproach them. Later on, if you don't play close attention to equip yourself the right way though, you'll have serious problems advancing, which I can say is a delicious meal, since you can't do without the crazy amount of items you get through, be it for any stat you desire. On that note, it's most important to delineate the capacity of builds you can do with each class you choose, you can be literally anything with any class, be it ranged, tank, melee, support, etc, although you do need to figure out the twerks of them first before you can really get to it, because they made it so you can't turn back too much on your skills decision, where you can only go back on 3 skill points, leaving you wonder why did they even put that system in. I guess to prevent some bad missclicks on skills you didn't wish to put skill points in.The multiplayer function is fun and explosive, as creatures invade your screen based on the amount of people that are playing with you. Other than that, it's not rewarding enough for what it does, where the items tend to be the same and the monsters get stronger and stronger, leaving you most of the time dead or pressing the health potion constantly, with no way to go around it, since there are a screen full at theme at every turn.Overall, it's the nicest action rpg out there, promising future installments to overcome each time the Runic Games team decides to go forward, which i wish they do, even if they change the IP, please keep the same action packed RPGs they do.P.S.: I didn't commentate the story, because I don't think they really wanted it to be that gratifying for the experience of the player, so i decided to just focus on what they focused to make the game great.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Best ARPG I've played to date. Why?- Casual gamer Friendly!- Although there is, what may seem at first, a limited number of classes the skill selection makes for at least 3 or 4 different sub-variations for each class. Replay value is great, although leveling is a test of patience. Capping taking roughly 2 complete playthroughs.- Graphics are not as hard on the average CPU that us mortals can afford. I prefer stylized graphics over realistic graphics because they are never out of style or look dated like most other 3D games.- It offers an Endgame consisting of Mapworks, a tool that allows you to run random dungeons of a level of your choosing (up to 105), and Tarroch's Tomb, a relentless 10 wave gauntlet that drops loot every wave you beat but disappears if you die (Wave 1 comprised of lvl 100 enemies and wave 10 of lvl 199 enemies).- The loot system actually feels FAIR!!! *coughs* Diablo III *coughs*- Moddability adds heaps to the game including a difficulty increase and class changes that increase replay value. Downside is modded game saves are different than stock and you can only play with people that have the same mods. Items can not be crossed from modded to unmodded.- If you get bored or just want to test limits you can duplicate items for money or utility by using a stash and save file manuever. You could also use console to spawn items but you will be labeled as a cheater. The ability to do these cheats adds a lot to the experienced of a gamer that is NOT HARDCORE. Casual gamers need to be catered to too.The only real downside I found was the relentlessness when making ability choices. MARK MY WORDS: You cannot respec more than the last 3 abilities you leveled or chose. This means you must level up a character from scratch to try a different build and will probably have to make 2 almost identical characters to fix a stupid choice mistake you made on your first try at a class. Some people love this feature but I believe it would be better if you could just have 2 sub-class slots like you have in WoW or if you could get an option to reset points after completing the game. Just my 2 cents.Please buy this and enjoy.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												This is one game that begs for DLC. Only three classes? You've got to be kidding me. That said, onto the good points. This is like Diablo 2, with a few good ideas tacked on, and placed in a fully 3D world. You'll have to forgive the DIablo comparisons, but this game warrants them: it was made by several ex-Diablo Blizzard crew members, and the polish shows. This is about the most comprehensively fun aRPG I have played since the release of D2. Do I like it better than Grim Dawn? Hell yes. Do I like it better than Path of Exile? Well, kinda. Yes, but the price point on Path sells it better; though in my mind, this is a more polished product. Do I like it better than D2? It follows in the same footsteps, so it is a more modern, updated version at its heart.I must at least add that for the price tag, it is the most fun "Diablo-like" I have played in about 5+ years, and could easily handwrestle the latest Blizzard release, Diablo 3 if it had tacked on more DLC. The endgame content on this, unfortunately, shortened my journey somewhat. The story is miles above the first Torchlight, and feel more coherent. Here, I feel a sense of *fighting* baddies, making my journey more meaningful. In the last game, everything seemed like an excuse to slay everything around me. This game  reverses the flow, putting plot first, and then allows the killing to begin in sequence, as the game world opens up. No more swimming for a portal that leads into an ever-downward dungeon. Here, there are separate areas, and new ideas, including some not present in D3, and certainly a better skill system than the latter. The first game was a nice time-waster. This one ties that problem up with a new plot, and several better ideas. I still think there should be DLC packs. This game calls for at least 3 more classes, to add online variety, and inspire players to frequent it more often. The narrative is well-done. The gameplay has a few twists on par with D3's treasure goblins. Visuals and art, check: graphics are top-notch. Audio is sufficient, nothing lacking, plenty of variety, no critical mistakes. Everything has an emphatic and crisp thump to it, and objects and fighting have loud *clangs,* and sound realistic, as well as sufficiently solid. Something Path of Exile lacks, I'm afraid. Collision detection is not finicky, like the latter, either. If anything, the only near miss is that emphatic lack of end-game content, along with replay value; easy levelling up to cap; and the few, uninspiring classes that would have been fixed with a shiny bit of DLC.At the time of release, this would have been a 9.5/10. At this point, I feel safer giving it an 8/10, as it is fun, polished, and has variety. Time will tell whether Torchlight supports an online community, and is willing to expand open its gameplay to more modes and challenges. Not in this release, I'm afraid. One thing is for certain: I will be first in line waiting for Torchlight 3. Let's hope for future news! Cheers. :D

												I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like. I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

Posted: December 1, 2013
												I honestly couldn’t believe it at first, but Torchlight II is indeed a massive improvement over the original. I can’t tell you how it compares to Diablo or other Diablo clones, but I can tell you it’s an action RPG that trounces its predecessor in terms of variety and breadth of content.At its base TII has you doing the same things as in the original Torchlight, but Runic Games seems to have done everything it could to make grinding for look more exciting with more places to go, more interesting classes, and more abilities to unlock.Instead of just running around in one town, one main dungeon, and a bunch of extra random dungeons, TII gives you an actual world to explore, split into several environments, each with a main and side dungeons as well as its own visual identity. The first thing I noticed about TII in videos was probably that it had a distinctly different and livelier color palette than the first game. TII looks fresher and a lot more aesthetically pleasing than the first game pretty much just due to better art direction. The first two areas in particular -- a steppe inhabited by monks, and a snowy mountainside, really helped draw me into the game.All TII’s new classes seem to be interesting departures from the norm. In the original Torchlight I ended up picking the class that felt most familiar to me which was the warrior/tank dude. The closest thing in TII is the Berserker which I ended up enjoying a lot more. Yeah Berserkers still just tank everywhere, but the added focus on critical hits, their berserker meter and weapons like claws instead of swords and shields makes playing the class more interesting in my opinion.TII’s sound design also creates a great sense of tactile feedback. Not only does the impact of landing hits in combat sound satisfying, but even the menu interface feels and sounds better when you’re assigning upgrade points and unlocking abilities. I think it helps drive home a sense of real craftsmanship that reminds you TII was indeed made by professional game developers.The best thing Runic did to help get people into TII was creating its excellent demo, which by itself I found to be pretty addicting. It’s basically the first area -- the steppe, stopping after the completion of the first main quest. And even afterwards you can still just mess around in that area which is what I did for a while before buying the game. Once you do you can carry your progress over.TII also adds a New Game+ in which you loop your old character back through the game with enemies leveled higher. You can do this and have enemies level ever higher five times (for a total of six runs through the game). You can keep looping infinitely after that but enemies won’t get any stronger. TII also has multiplayer but I’ve actually only done solo so far.Lastly, TII has been reported to be able to run on integrated graphics, though I can’t confirm this 100 percent.$20 might be a lot for an indie game, but after learning how much content and variety was packed into TII, $20 feels like an excellent price for it.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												It lost some of the great functions of the first one, like the gems adding up to being better on the trasmuter, instead now they just turn into blood ember, chaos ember, iron ember or void ember, of the respective level. Although I can get why they did this, so you don't get stuck on farm hunting these gems into despair, they made it easy for you to farm them, so you now can get them progressing through the game.The visuals tend to have a grand variety through the game, as you can have an icy tundra first, then have an hot desert the next. Animations are fluid and creative, but it's sad that for the most part the only thing you see is the slicing of flesh and a splatter of blood covering your screen when it's full of monsters. But they did improve a lot on the different type of monsters on the account of the first, let alone the animations that accompany their entrances into the map, which is a nice feature to not just have them all roaming the map.The gameplay is still as fast as the first, where the only time you have to breath is the time you choose, since you don't have to stop by the town everytime you need to sell your items. The monsters, champions and bosses all present their unique signature attacks, that make you adjust your tactic on how to aproach them. Later on, if you don't play close attention to equip yourself the right way though, you'll have serious problems advancing, which I can say is a delicious meal, since you can't do without the crazy amount of items you get through, be it for any stat you desire. On that note, it's most important to delineate the capacity of builds you can do with each class you choose, you can be literally anything with any class, be it ranged, tank, melee, support, etc, although you do need to figure out the twerks of them first before you can really get to it, because they made it so you can't turn back too much on your skills decision, where you can only go back on 3 skill points, leaving you wonder why did they even put that system in. I guess to prevent some bad missclicks on skills you didn't wish to put skill points in.The multiplayer function is fun and explosive, as creatures invade your screen based on the amount of people that are playing with you. Other than that, it's not rewarding enough for what it does, where the items tend to be the same and the monsters get stronger and stronger, leaving you most of the time dead or pressing the health potion constantly, with no way to go around it, since there are a screen full at theme at every turn.Overall, it's the nicest action rpg out there, promising future installments to overcome each time the Runic Games team decides to go forward, which i wish they do, even if they change the IP, please keep the same action packed RPGs they do.P.S.: I didn't commentate the story, because I don't think they really wanted it to be that gratifying for the experience of the player, so i decided to just focus on what they focused to make the game great.
